title-group.article-title: A comparative study of the effects of cotton fiber length parameters on modeling yarn properties

author-notes.corresp: Xiaoliang Cui, SRRC ARS USDA, 1100 Robert E. Lee Boulevard, New Orleans, LA 70124, USA. Email: leon.cui@ars.usda.gov

abstract.p: Fiber length is one of the key properties of cotton and has important influences on yarn production and yarn quality. Various parameters have been developed to characterize cotton fiber length in the past decades. This study was carried out to investigate the effects of these parameters and their combinations on yarn properties. Linear regression models with different numbers of fiber length parameters and their combinations were developed for predicting ring and open-end (OE) spun yarns’ properties. The R2 and Mallows’ Cp plots of the models were compared for model selections. The results indicate that, for predicting a yarn property, a model usually involves more than three length parameters to achieve better prediction when considering the R2 and Cp values. This may be because only one single length parameter cannot sufficiently represent fiber length characteristics. The results also show that the variations in fiber length distributions play important roles in predicting yarn properties, such as strength and irregularity. The best prediction models for the properties of different yarns (ring, OE) include different combinations of length parameters. Not all yarn properties can be well predicted by linear regression models with length parameters: other fiber properties (strength, micronaire, etc.) need to be included to further improve the models.

body.p: Cotton as raw material can account for more than 60% of all cost in yarn production. In 2011, the cotton price reached a historic high of more than US$5 per kilograms.1 The dramatic cotton price increase promoted research on better prediction of yarn properties from cotton properties to better select cotton and reduce cost. Fiber length is one of the key properties and has important influences on yarn production and yarn quality, affecting issues such as yarn strength, uniformity and hairiness.2,3 Various parameters have been developed to characterize cotton fiber length and to predict yarn properties in past decades, such as Mean Length (ML), Upper Half Mean Length (UHML), Upper Quartile Length (UQL), Short Fiber Content (SFC), etc.4 Although these parameters are all statistics of fiber length distribution, they represent different length characteristics of a cotton sample. The mathematical description of the cotton fiber length has been investigated in order to facilitate the computation and utilization of length parameters.5 Obviously, UQL contains more information about the longer fibers in the sample, but not much information about the shorter fibers in the sample. It is the opposite for SFC. Further, even though some fiber parameters have a very high correlation coefficient, such as between UQL and UHML, the relationship is never perfectly linear because of the fiber length distribution. Then questions can be asked: Do certain length parameters predict yarn properties better than others depending on the yarn types (ring or open-end (OE), for example)? Is it beneficial to have various length parameters that can be calculated from fiber length distribution?

Length parameters have been involved in the yarn quality prediction models. Some of these parameters have very different definitions; in addition, cotton length distributions contain complex statistical features.6 Consequently, although these length parameters can be conveniently obtained or computed from the same length distribution results, their relationships to yarn properties may not work in the same way; in other words, each length parameter’s significance on predicting yarn properties can be different. A specific example is the impact of short fibers on yarn properties.7 There are different short fiber parameters; their capabilities in predicting yarn properties have been compared and searching for an optimal parameter has been carried out.8

Modern testing devices, such as the Uster Advanced Information System™ (AFIS) and High Volume Instrument™ (HVI), are able to report a number of cotton fiber quality parameters relatively quickly. These devices are convenient for obtaining large quantities of data, which help researchers to better understand the quality of the tested sample, and develop statistics models to predict yarn properties from cotton fiber property parameters.9 The applications of the statistical models include studies such as accessing cotton technological values based on the model’s between yarn quality parameters and HVI-reported fiber parameters,10 and using HVI parameters for regression analyses of cotton yarn quality characteristics and processing performance,11 etc. Recent work indicates that the length distribution can be estimated from HVI test results. Any and all fiber length parameters can be calculated from fiber length distributions.

For the above reasons, we conducted this study to see how many and what length parameters are needed to improve the accuracy in predicting yarn properties by including different length parameters and their combinations in the prediction models. The combinations of these length parameters can provide insights to the impacts of fiber length characteristics on certain yarn properties, as well as to the potential of using optimized length parameters in predicting certain yarn properties. We would like to emphasize that the main purpose of this study is not to develop a set of universal equations to predict yarn properties; rather, we would like to demonstrate that by tailor-selecting different fiber length parameters and their combinations, better yarn property prediction can be achieved. Further, this supports the importance of obtaining fiber length distribution so that various fiber length parameters can be calculated and used.

sec.title: Materials and method
sec.p: Detailed comparisons on the above short fiber parameters have been reported.8
The yarn quality properties predicted by using the models were strength, elongation, irregularity (uniformity), thick places, thin places, neps, and ends-down.

The samples used in this study included 28 different cottons that were provided by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agriculture Marketing Service (AMS) for a SFC study. The samples were measured using HVI and AFIS. Ten samples were taken from each bale, and five replicates for each sample were tested. Each rep had 5000 individual fibers tested on AFIS. SFC16 mm, LHML, Rel_SFC, FFP, and FFI were calculated from fiber length distributions obtained from AFIS. The properties of these samples representatively cover a broad range (Table 1). The samples were made into OE and ring-spun yarns at USDA Agricultural Research Service (ARS) Cotton Quality Research Station (CQRS) at Clemson, SC. Table 1.

Linear regression models have been developed to use fiber length parameters to predict yarn properties. In these models, only length parameters were included in the models as regressors. We compared not only the R2 values of the models, but also their Mallows’ Cp values to examine if a model is proper.18 For a total of N parameters, the computation of Cp values is shown in Equation (1):19 (1)Cp=SSEp/S2- (N-2p ) where SSEp is the sum of squared errors of the model with p regressors (the number of parameters plus the intercept) and s2 is the full model mean squared error. If a model’s Cp value is approaching the value of p in that model, the model is considered more proper than a model that has a larger Cp value. A step-wise algorithm was used to develop the models. The regressions were computed using the statistical software package SAS.

sec.title: Yarn strength
sec.p:
Linear regressions of each yarn property were carried out with 1, 2, 3 , … , up to 15 length parameters, as listed in the previous section. Taking yarn strength as an example, 15 regression equations were constructed when only using one length parameter (and an intercept) in each equation. The models with the best R2 and Cp values were selected. Figures 1 and 2 compare the different ring and OE-spun yarn strength models’ R2 and Cp values according to the combinations of regressors of length parameters. In these figures, the x-axis is sorted by the number of regressors. The comparisons of R2 and Cp values between these models indicate that, for both ring and OE-spun yarns, when length parameters are involved to predict the strength, four-parameter models (p = 5) perform better than other models with fewer parameters. When the number of length parameters in a model increases beyond four, there is no significant increase of model R2. The model becomes more complicated and the Cp value starts to drift away from the Cp = p line, which indicates that the model deteriorates. Figure 1.
The changes of R2 (a) and Cp (b) values according to the number of regressors in the ring-spun yarn strength models.
Figure 2.
The changes of R2 (a) and Cp (b) values according to the number of regressors in the open-end-spun yarn strength models.

Table 2 lists the parameters that produced the best predictions (highest R2) among all four-parameter linear regression models used for ring and OE-spun yarns; the corresponding R2 and Cp values are listed in the table as well. The adjusted R2 values are also included in the table. One interesting observation is that the parameters for OE and ring yarns are the same, which indicates that fiber length parameters have similar effects in ring and OE-spun yarn strength. It is well known that cotton fiber length has an important influence on yarn strength; the parameters in Table 2 indicate that this influence can be mainly described by the composite effects of longer fibers and shorter fibers, as well as the variation of the fiber length distribution (CV). sec.title: Irregularity
sec.p:
Figures 3 and 4 compare the different ring and OE-spun yarn irregularity CV models’ R2 and Cp values according to the combinations of regressors of length parameters. The figures show that the length parameters perform differently in ring and OE-spun yarn irregularity. Considering both the approaching Cp values and R2, for ring-spun yarns it takes five parameters (p = 6) in the model and three parameters (p = 4) for OE-spun yarns. The parameters that yielded best results are listed in Table 3. Figures 3 and 4 and Table 3 show that the effects of fiber length parameters on the irregularity of ring-spun yarns are different from those of OE-spun yarns. Figure 3.

It is worth noting that, from the above figures and tables, for both ring and OE-spun yarns, the CV of fiber length obviously is an important factor on yarn strength and irregularity. Furthermore, when comparing the ring and OE parameters in Table 3, it can be seen that for OE yarns there is no short fiber parameter involved. This indicates that OE yarn’s evenness is less susceptible to the shorter fibers within the cotton, although there have been a variety of different earlier reports: some considered short fibers improve the evenness in certain cases, while some reached the opposite conclusion.20,.21

sec.title: Thick places
sec.p:
Figures 5 and 6 compare the R2 and Cp values of the different ring and OE-spun yarn thick places models using length parameters as regressors. The figures also show that the effects of length parameters on ring and OE-spun yarns are different. Figure 5.
The changes of R2 (a) and Cp (b) values according to the number of regressors in the ring-spun yarn thick place models.
Figure 6.
The changes of R2 (a) and Cp (b) values according to the number of regressors in the open-end-spun yarn thick place models.

Table 4 lists the best parameters for yarn thick places based on Cp and R2 values. From Table 4 and Figures 5 and 6, it can be seen that, for ring-spun yarn, it takes six length parameters to reach a proper model; the length parameters in the OE-spun yarn model is less complicated. The involvement of MLs and UQLs indicates that for OE-spun yarns, the longer fibers within the cotton play a more important role in forming thick places. The reason could be that with longer fibers it is easier to form a wrapper fiber layer around the twisted fiber core, thus causing a larger portion of thick places.22 Table 4.

sec.title: Thin places
sec.p:
Figures 7 and 8 compare the R2 and Cp values of the different models for ring and OE-spun yarn thin places according to the combinations of regressors of length parameters. The shapes of the plots are similar to those of the thick places models. The selected models based on Cp and R2 values are listed in Table 5. When comparing the ring-spun yarn and OE-spun yarn length parameters listed in Tables 4 and 5, it can be seen that for thick and thin places, ring-spun yarns are sensitive to the cotton’s length; the high R2 values from a combination of different length parameters show that fiber length characteristics account for a main portion of the variations in thick and thin places. sec.title: Other properties
sec.p: Our models indicate that not all yarn properties can be well predicted by using length property parameters. In addition, length properties could perform very differently for ring-spun yarns and OE-spun yarns. For neps, length property linear models can reach R2 = 0.75 for ring-spun yarns when eight parameters are used, but the R2 is less than 0.6 for OE-spun yarns with a proper Cp. For ends-down, when seven length parameters are used, the linear model can reach R2 = 0.83 for OE-spun yarns, but the R2 is less than 0.5 for ring-spun yarns with a proper Cp.

The results for ring- and OE-spun yarn elongation models all had low R2 values, which indicate that the linear model may not be sufficient or other fiber properties may have significantly larger effects on yarn breaking elongation than length properties.
We attempted to introduce square terms of the fiber length parameters, but the models did not exhibit significant improvement.

sec.title: Additional discussion
sec.p: From Table 2–5, it can be observed that the R2 values for OE-spun yarn models usually are lower than those for ring-spun yarn models. This indicated that for ring-spun yarns, the length parameters have better performance in explaining the trends of the yarn quality properties; this is supported by the high R2 values, which indicate that the combinations have statistically significant impacts on the specified yarn properties. It is also widely observed that OE spinning has a lower fiber length quality requirement than ring spinning, and fiber strength plays a larger role in OE yarn strength than ring yarn strength. The length parameters listed in Tables 2–5 illustrated the effects of the different combinations of length parameters on yarn properties; these results also show the importance of obtaining comprehensive information about a cotton’s length distributions, instead of a limited number of individual length parameters, in order to enhance the prediction of yarn qualities from cotton fiber length and other properties.

It is important that for the yarn properties and length parameters, the linear model’s assumptions can be satisfied: (1) residuals have a random pattern; (2) the residuals are close to a normal distribution. Residual plots against the response variables, predicted values, and predictor variables support that the residuals are random. Q-Q plots support that the residuals satisfactorily fit the normal distribution. These residual plots of the ring-spun yarn strength model are shown in Figures 9 and 10. Other models have similar plots that support the linear model assumptions. Figure 9.
Residual-predicted values plot for the ring-spun yarn strength model.
Figure 10.
Residual Q-Q plot for the ring-spun yarn strength model.

It is not the intention of this paper to develop a set of universally applicable equations for predicting yarn properties. The equations developed in this paper will not be the optimal with other yarn production lines that have differ machines and settings, neither with yarns of different yarn parameters, such as count and twist level. This study demonstrated the benefit of obtaining fiber length distribution so that different length parameters can be obtained to suit different applications. This study also demonstrated the need and method for individual yarn production lines and products to develop their own equations that have different constants and maybe even different combinations of fiber length parameters. Most modern mills have a large amount of data through regular yarn and fiber testing, and the development of such equations is not very difficult, especially when faculty and students of a textile college can be involved.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The cotton fiber length parameters represent different characteristics of cotton length distributions. An investigation was carried out on the effects of 15 conventional and non-conventional cotton fiber length parameters on yarn properties. Linear regression models with different numbers of fiber length parameters and combinations were developed to predict ring- and OE-spun yarns’ properties, including strength, irregularity, thick places, thin places, neps, ends-down, and elongation. The R2 and Cp plots of the models were compared for model selections. The results indicate that, for predicting a property, a model involves more than three length parameters to achieve better results when considering the R2 and Mallows’ Cp values. For example, with only length parameters, four-parameter models are more proper models for predicting yarn strength. This is because only one single length parameter cannot sufficiently represent fiber length characteristics. The results also show that the variations in fiber length distributions play important roles in predicting yarn properties, such as strength and irregularity. Best prediction models for different yarn (ring, OE) properties (strength, irregularity, etc.) include different length parameters. For example, the models for ring and OE yarn thick places are very different. Not all yarn properties (such as yarn breaking elongation) can be well predicted by linear regression models with length parameters and other fiber properties (strength, micronaire, etc.) needing to be included to further improve the models. The results demonstrated the benefit of obtaining fiber length distributions so that various length parameters can be calculated and the yarn property prediction can be improved.
